text1: Do you have permission to go out and take confession today ?
text2: Commend we today forth To tell in our house of tomorrow ?

text1: Today's a holiday , so the beggar's shop is shut .
text2: By the time you have looked this far , Till tomorrow is the holiday , The beggar's shop is shut up .

text1: Her body sleeps in Capels ' monument , And her immortal part with angels lives .
text2: She sleeps in Capel's tomb , and her life lives in the angels .

text1: Then the window lets day in , and life goes out the window .
text2: Then , apart from that window , life relives , and goes from being .

text1: Wouldst thou withdraw it ?
text2: May I have him ?

text1: Why , how now , Juliet ?
text2: What , now , Juliet ?

text1: Wait , Tybalt , wait !
text2: Stay , Tybalt , stay !

text1: What a man , young lady .
text2: How sweet a man he is .

text1: Why are you knocking so hard ?
text2: Why dost thou so hard on me ?

text1: I won't miss any chance to send my love to you .
text2: Not to my marriage will I omit A chance to let my love speak .

text1: How long has he been there ?
text2: And how long is it that's kept ?

text1: Romeo can , Though heaven can not .
text2: But heaven can't , but Rome can .

text1: Were you talking about Juliet ?
text2: Did you hear of Juliet ?

text1: Tis now near night .
text2: It's almost midnight .

text1: I am too sore enpierced with his shaft To soar with his light feathers , and so bound , I can not bound a pitch above dull woe .
text2: I am too sore to fly with his light feather feather clays , and so I am also bound by a deep , dark abyss to fall .

text1: How sweet is love itself possessed When but love's shadows are so rich in joy !
text2: Oh , how sweet is love , when it's so rich in joy !

text1: O happy dagger , This is thy sheath .
text2: Happy dagger , it's your holster .

text1: She's dead , deceased , she's dead .
text2: She was killed .

text1: Let me be ta'en .
text2: I'll take that .

text1: Shall I believe That unsubstantial death is amorous , And that the lean abhorred monster keeps Thee here in dark to be his paramour ?
text2: Have I truly believed that the unsubstantial death is a romantic , and that the slimy monster will keep you alive as his lout by promising you his devotion ?

text1: Villain am I none .
text2: I am a villain , not an actor .

text1: Supper is done , and we shall come too late .
text2: We all had to stay past dinner , but to tell the truth , our dinner is ready now .

text1: What eye but such an eye would spy out such a quarrel ?
text2: And what eye could see such a quarrel ?

text1: Tis late .
text2: That's too late .

text1: Yet I can not choose but laugh To think it should leave crying and say "ay." And yet , I warrant , it had upon its brow A bump as big as a young cockerel's stone , A perilous knock , and it cried bitterly .
text2: I knew this guy would toss a big , dark , and painful blow , and weep bitterly .

text1: Then hie you hence to Friar Lawrence's cell .
text2: So go to a cell of the friar Lawrence .

text2: Why , that's a good sound for silver , sir , but the sound that falls off gold ,

text2: I'll get to my sin again .

text2: You know why the rush is on .

text1: Where is she ?
text2: Where she is , she ?

text1: Monday , my lord .
text2: Sia . , Monday , my lord .

text2: What said you by your height , my noble Brutus ?

text1: Inside the little rind of this weak flower , there is both poison and powerful medicine .
text2: This flower , by what fool is 't To groat , pinlet's 't , and spurn So ?

text2: Saint Francis , quoth the duke !

text1: If they do see thee they will murder thee .
text2: Unless they see you , they'll kill you .

text1: I am sped .
text2: I have to hurry .

text1: Be quiet , for shame !
text2: But keep quiet , for shame !

text1: Right , and well said .
text2: Well , and I say this very wisely .

text1: I will be brief because I'm not going to live long enough to tell a boring story .
text2: I will shortly be brief Of my long experience to tell a dull tale .

text1: So will ye , I am sure , that you love me .
text2: I see you'll love me as well .

text1: How art thou out of breath when thou hast breath To say to me that thou art out of breath ?
text2: How do you mean by this , saying that you have no breath when you're filled with breath ?

text1: Go hence .
text2: So go .

text1: Either my eyesight fails , or thou look'st pale .
text2: I , or you , or none of you , either are looking pale , I'm looking for him .

text1: Oh my , my bones ache so much .
text2: My flesh is sore .

text1: Old Montague is here , and he's waving his sword around just to make me mad .
text2: Montague , and as mad As ever did waving his sword about .

text1: Is the worst well ?
text2: Is 't the worst ?

text1: Calling death banishment is like cutting off my head with a golden ax and smiling while I'm being murdered .
text2: No , sir , like I'll cleave my head off With golden axe and smile when I am murdered .

text1: Let the blood rushing to my cheeks be calmed .
text2: For my beard , let me not brook the blood in my cheek .
